text: <@U243UT96G|mo> has joined the channel
<@U0B9N0HF0> <http://sploid.gizmodo.com/master-bartender-makes-ersatz-campari-from-scratch-1785698719>

attachments.title: Master Bartender Makes a Campari Clone From Scratch
attachments.text: Campari—the bright red liquor best known as the start of the negroni—is delicious. But what the hell is it, exactly? The few people who know have kept the recipe a secret for well over a century. That didn’t stop master bartender Hiroyasu Kayama from trying to make his own.
attachments.fallback: Sploid: Master Bartender Makes a Campari Clone From Scratch

text: also watching that guy work is amazing
Dig it!

A friend of mine let me try some strange variation of a Negroni he made with some type of Campari alternative (and I think it had gin also?). Anyway, it was shockingly delicious and I cannot remember what the Campari substitute was called :(
Bigallet China China Amer Bitter Liqueu?
Or Aperol (essentially same thing as Campari)
Gran Classico from Tempus Fugit
Luxardo Bitter
none of those sound familiar
i just texted him because now this is killing me
:thumbsup:
>A negroni, and equal parts gin, vermouth, and calisaya, with an orange peel.
:yum:
calisaya huh? Interesting. I’ll have to check it out.
Opening tonight and i’m excited to try it. My cousin-in-law is working there and said the food is real real good. <http://www.jacquelinepdx.com/>

attachments.title: Welcome
attachments.text: Portland Oregon Pacific Northwest Cuisine Fine Dining Neighborhood restaurant seafood cocktails wine list desserts hosford abernathy Southeast Portland Dining

text: YUM seafood.
Oysters for the win
i have to say, i dont eat oysters, but with the rage in NYC and all the oysters either being NE or PNW - i expected there to be more of a presence of oyster/champagne/snack bars here.
More a Seattle thing?

<@U0B9N0HF0> i’m super late to this convo but i was literally googling calisaya last night as it’s listed as an ingredient in a cocktail i want to try for potential wedding cocktail hour. let me know if you end up getting some and liking it!
and trent cool to hear you dig it!
will do!
<@U0DCXC37U> it is super weird that there’s not more/better seafood in portland in general
even on the coast its surprisingly hard to find oysters
<@U0260V1BX> totally! i love seafood btw, and def noticed an absence
my husband and i went to an oyster farm in a town called oysterville and we couldnt get oysters there
lol
There is salmon
Everywhere
more context: we wanted shucked oysters to eat there but they were only selling bags of unshucked. The lady said “we’re out of shucked oysters”… :neutral_face:
yes there is an abundance of salmon
and its the best salmon

so one more Q for the foodie crew - we have like 4 weeks left of eating out potential before life implodes…. which in workaholic parenting life means 1 date night left…. where should we go? before the sequestering begins?
Tusk is getting all the hype right now
Mae (a southern pop-up in the back of Old Salt) is supposed to be _real_ good
DOC is super delicious
been wanting to try Han Oak - <@U0B9N0HF0> you went right?
also if you like seafood I’ve heard Roe is awesome
Mae is fucking dope
Coquine is really cute. Yeah, went last Friday. Very cute too. You can eat in the courtyard. The food didn’t explode my taste buds like a Ava Gene’s or a Le Pigeon, but for $35, it was a great time!
oh i love Coquine
Go to mae you will be stuffed forever
you guys are amazing.

:slightly_smiling_face: Here’s photos of Tusk (new restaurant from Josh McFadden of Ava Gene’s on 24th and Burnside). Looks really cute. Middle eastern inspired <http://pdx.eater.com/2016/8/22/12585068/tusk-restaurant-photos-middle-eastern-burnside#6624019>

attachments.title: See Inside Tusk, Opening August 22
attachments.text: Old Levant space is transformed by new Middle Eastern-inspired restaurant
attachments.fallback: Eater Portland: See Inside Tusk, Opening August 22

text: i'm super late to the oyster convo, but my favorite place to go is hama hama oyster farm on the OP, right off the 101.  i always stop there on my way to go see family
the reason there isn't better seafood in portland is because pacific seafoods basically has a lock on seafood supplying for portland - literally everyone gets their seafood from the same supplier
there's a decent spot in seaside called the buoy that has fresh fish and good chowder.  also local ocean in newport, which actually puts out their own boats.  but neither of those places are in town
<@U243UT96G> :heart: hama hama
Parents live in PT. so stop by every time I go up and come back down! Amazing
oh cool!  my aunt (midori's mom) and my grandpa who just passed lived up there
the aunt is there still.  so i go up there often.  PT's fish market on the wharf is my dream local seafood source
Yeah. And Pour House is dream beer hall :)
On another note, here's a list of some notable restaurants opening this year <http://pdx.eater.com/2016/8/24/12624098/restaurants-opening-soon-portland-oregon>
